Rules.Title: Unnecessary async/await usage
Rules.Description: There are some async methods where there is no need to use async/await keywords. It is important to detect this kind of misuse because adding the async modifier comes at a price. AsyncFixer automatically removes async/await keywords from those methods.

Rules.Title: Long-running or blocking operations inside an async method
Rules.Description: Developers use some potentially long-running or blocking operations inside async methods even though there are corresponding asynchronous versions of these methods in .NET or third-party libraries. Some examples for such operations: Task.Wait(), Task.Result, StreamReader.ReadToEnd(), Thread.Sleep(), etc.

Rules.Title: Fire-and-forget async-void methods and delegates
Rules.Description: Some async methods and delegates are fire-and-forget, which return void. Unless a method is only called as an event handler, it must be awaitable. Otherwise, it is a code smell because it complicates control flow and makes error detection/correction difficult. Unhandled exceptions in those async-void methods and delegates will crash the process as well.

Rules.Title: Fire-and-forget async call inside an using block
Rules.Description: Inside a using block, developers insert a fire-and-forget async call which uses a disposable object as a parameter or target object. It can cause potential exceptions or wrong results.

Rules.Title: Downcasting from a nested task to an outer task.
Rules.Description: Downcasting from a nested task to a task or awaiting a nested task is dangerous. There is no way to wait for and get the result of the child task. This usually occurs when mixing async/await keywords with the old threading APIs such as TaskFactory.StartNew.

Rules.Title: StringComparison is missing
IEqualityComparer<string> or IComparer<string> is missing
Add argument name to improve readability
Use Task.ConfigureAwait(false)
Use Array.Empty<T>()
Use String.Equals instead of equality operator
Add a comma after the last value
Add StructLayoutAttribute
Add regex evaluation timeout
Mark attributes with AttributeUsageAttribute
IFormatProvider is missing
Do not raise reserved exception type
Types should not extend System.ApplicationException
Do not raise System.ApplicationException type
Specify the parameter name in ArgumentException
Prefer return collection abstraction instead of implementation
Abstract types should not have public or internal constructors
Do not declare static members on generic types
Use EventArgs.Empty
Use direct methods instead of LINQ methods
Use StringComparer.GetHashCode instead of string.GetHashCode
Return Task.FromResult instead of returning null
Add RegexOptions.ExplicitCapture
Use an explicit StringComparer when possible
Implement the functionality instead of throwing NotImplementedException
Fix TODO comment
Do not remove original exception
Optimize StringBuilder usage
Combine LINQ methods
Remove useless OrderBy call
Optimize Enumerable.Count() usage
Use an overload with a CancellationToken argument
Do not tag instance fields with ThreadStaticAttribute
Do not use dangerous threading methods
Make class static
Remove empty statement
Make method static
Do not write your own certificate validation method
Flow the cancellation token
Make property static
Do not use blocking calls in an async method
Use nameof operator in ArgumentException
Remove useless ToString call
Do not use blocking call in a sync method (need to make containing method async)
Use EventHandler<T> to declare events
Declare types in namespaces
File name must match type name
Type name should not match containing namespace
Validate arguments correctly in iterator methods
Method is too long
Replace constant Enum.ToString with nameof
Make class sealed
Embed the caught exception as innerException
Do not use finalizer
Do not call overridable members in constructor
Class name should end with 'Attribute'
Class name should end with 'Exception'
Class name should end with 'EventArgs'
The value returned by Stream.Read/Stream.ReadAsync is not used
Method overrides should not change parameter defaults
Non-flags enums should not be marked with "FlagsAttribute"
Use Where before OrderBy
Avoid locking on publicly accessible instance
Default ValueType.Equals or HashCode is used for struct's equality
Hash table unfriendly type is used in a hash table
Use Guid.Empty
Invalid parameter name for nullable attribute
Non-constant static fields should not be visible
Obsolete attributes should include explanations
Avoid using redundant else
Do not throw from a finally block
Avoid comparison with bool constant
Avoid implicit culture-sensitive methods
Do not use implicit culture-sensitive ToString
Do not use implicit culture-sensitive ToString in interpolated strings
A class that provides Equals(T) should implement IEquatable<T>
Use 'Cast' instead of 'Select' to cast
Flow the cancellation token using .WithCancellation()
Use a cancellation token using .WithCancellation()
Method overrides should not omit params keyword
NaN should not be used in comparisons
ConstructorArgument parameters should exist in constructors
Local variable should not hide other symbols
Anonymous delegates should not be used to unsubscribe from Events
Do not throw from a finalizer
Parameters with [DefaultParameterValue] attributes should also be marked [Optional]
Use [DefaultParameterValue] instead of [DefaultValue]
Optimize string method usage
Remove empty else/finally block
Sender should be 'this' for instance events
Sender should be 'null' for static events
EventArgs should not be null
A class that provides CompareTo(T) should implement IComparable<T>
A class that implements IEquatable<T> should override Equals(object)
A class that implements IComparable<T> should also implement IEquatable<T>
A class that implements IComparable<T> or IComparable should override comparison operators
Use indexer instead of LINQ methods
Use Explicit enum value instead of 0
Await task before disposing resources
String contains an implicit end of line character
Make member readonly

Rules.Description: All diagnostics of XML documentation comments has been disabled due to the current project configuration.

Rules.Title: Invalid settings file
Rules.Description: The stylecop.json settings file could not be loaded due to a deserialization error.

Rules.Title: Keywords must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: The spacing around a C# keyword is incorrect.

Rules.Title: Commas must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: The spacing around a comma is incorrect, within a C# code file.

Rules.Title: Semicolons must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: The spacing around a semicolon is incorrect, within a C# code file.

Rules.Title: Symbols must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: The spacing around an operator symbol is incorrect, within a C# code file.

Rules.Title: Documentation lines must begin with single space
Rules.Description: A line within a documentation header above a C# element does not begin with a single space.

Rules.Title: Single line comments must begin with single space
Rules.Description: A single-line comment within a C# code file does not begin with a single space.

Rules.Title: Preprocessor keywords must not be preceded by space
Rules.Description: A C# preprocessor-type keyword is preceded by space.

Rules.Title: Operator keyword must be followed by space
Rules.Description: The operator keyword within a C# operator overload method is not followed by any whitespace.

Rules.Title: Opening parenthesis must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: An opening parenthesis within a C# statement is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Closing parenthesis must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: A closing parenthesis within a C# statement is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Opening square brackets must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: An opening square bracket within a C# statement is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Closing square brackets must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: A closing square bracket within a C# statement is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Opening braces must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: An opening brace within a C# element is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Closing braces must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: A closing brace within a C# element is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Opening generic brackets must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: An opening generic bracket within a C# element is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Closing generic brackets must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: A closing generic bracket within a C# element is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Opening attribute brackets must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: An opening attribute bracket within a C# element is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Closing attribute brackets must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: A closing attribute bracket within a C# element is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Nullable type symbols must not be preceded by space
Rules.Description: A nullable type symbol within a C# element is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Member access symbols must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: The spacing around a member access symbol is incorrect, within a C# code file.

Rules.Title: Increment decrement symbols must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: An increment or decrement symbol within a C# element is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Negative signs must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: A negative sign within a C# element is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Positive signs must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: A positive sign within a C# element is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Dereference and access of must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: A dereference symbol or an access-of symbol within a C# element is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Colons must be spaced correctly
Rules.Description: A colon within a C# element is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Code must not contain multiple whitespace in ARow
Rules.Description: The code contains multiple whitespace characters in a row.

Rules.Title: Code must not contain space after new keyword in implicitly typed array allocation
Rules.Description: An implicitly typed new array allocation within a C# code file is not spaced correctly.

Rules.Title: Use tabs correctly
Rules.Description: The code contains a tab or space character which is not consistent with the current project settings.

Rules.Title: Code must not contain trailing whitespace
Rules.Description: A line of code ends with a space, tab, or other whitespace characters before the end of line character(s).

Rules.Title: Do not prefix calls with base unless local implementation exists
Rules.Description: A call to a member from an inherited class begins with base., and the local class does not contain an override or implementation of the member.

Rules.Title: Prefix local calls with this
Rules.Description: A call to an instance member of the local class or a base class is not prefixed with 'this.', within a C# code file.

Rules.Title: Query clauses
Rules.Description: A C# query clause does not begin on the same line as the previous clause, or on the next line.

Rules.Title: Query clauses
Rules.Description: The clauses within a C# query expression are not all placed on the same line, and each clause is not placed on its own line.

Rules.Title: Query clauses
Rules.Description: A clause within a C# query expression begins on the same line as the previous clause, when the previous clause spans across multiple lines.

Rules.Title: Query clauses
Rules.Description: A clause within a C# query expression spans across multiple lines, and does not begin on its own line.

Rules.Title: Code must not contain empty statements
Rules.Description: The C# code contains an extra semicolon.

Rules.Title: Code must not contain multiple statements on one line
Rules.Description: The C# code contains more than one statement on a single line.

Rules.Title: Block statements must not contain embedded comments
Rules.Description: A C# statement contains a comment between the declaration of the statement and the opening brace of the statement.

Rules.Title: Block statements must not contain embedded regions
Rules.Description: A C# statement contains a region tag between the declaration of the statement and the opening brace of the statement.

Rules.Title: Opening parenthesis must be on declaration line
Rules.Description: The opening parenthesis or bracket in a call to a C# method or indexer, or the declaration of a method or indexer, is not placed on the same line as the method or indexer name.

Rules.Title: Closing parenthesis must be on line of last parameter
Rules.Description: The closing parenthesis or bracket in a call to a C# method or indexer, or the declaration of a method or indexer, is not placed on the same line as the last parameter.

Rules.Title: Closing parenthesis must be on line of opening parenthesis
Rules.Description: The closing parenthesis or bracket in a call to a C# method or indexer, or the declaration of a method or indexer, is not placed on the same line as the opening bracket when the element does not take any parameters.

Rules.Title: Comma must be on same line as previous parameter
Rules.Description: A comma between two parameters in a call to a C# method or indexer, or in the declaration of a method or indexer, is not placed on the same line as the previous parameter.

Rules.Title: Parameter list must follow declaration
Rules.Description: The start of the parameter list for a method or indexer call or declaration does not begin on the same line as the opening bracket, or on the line after the opening bracket.

Rules.Title: Parameter must follow comma
Rules.Description: A parameter within a C# method or indexer call or declaration does not begin on the same line as the previous parameter, or on the next line.

Rules.Title: Split parameters must start on line after declaration
Rules.Description: The parameters to a C# method or indexer call or declaration span across multiple lines, but the first parameter does not start on the line after the opening bracket.

Rules.Title: Parameters must be on same line or separate lines
Rules.Description: The parameters to a C# method or indexer call or declaration are not all on the same line or each on a separate line.

Rules.Title: Parameter must not span multiple lines
Rules.Description: A parameter to a C# method or indexer, other than the first parameter, spans across multiple lines.

Rules.Title: Comments must contain text
Rules.Description: The C# comment does not contain any comment text.

Rules.Title: Use built in type alias
Rules.Description: The code uses one of the basic C# types, but does not use the built-in alias for the type.

Rules.Title: Use string empty for empty strings
Rules.Description: The C# code includes an empty string, written as "".

Rules.Title: Do not place regions within elements
Rules.Description: The C# code contains a region within the body of a code element.

Rules.Title: Do not use regions
Rules.Description: The C# code contains a region.

Rules.Title: Use shorthand for nullable types
Rules.Description: The Nullable type has been defined not using the C# shorthand.

Rules.Title: Prefix calls correctly
Rules.Description: A call to a member is not prefixed with the 'this.', 'base.', 'object.' or 'typename.' prefix to indicate the intended method call, within a C# code file.

Rules.Title: Generic type constraints must be on own line
Rules.Description: A generic constraint on a type or method declaration is on the same line as the declaration, within a C# code file.

Rules.Title: Constructor initializer must be on own line
Rules.Description: A constructor initializer is on the same line as the constructor declaration, within a C# code file.

Rules.Title: Do not use default value type constructor
Rules.Description: A value type was constructed using the syntax new T().

Rules.Title: Use lambda syntax
Rules.Description: An anonymous method was declared using the form delegate (parameters) { }, when a lambda expression would provide equivalent behavior with the syntax (parameters) => { }.

Rules.Title: Use readable conditions
Rules.Description: A comparison was made between a variable and a literal or constant value, and the variable appeared on the right-hand side of the expression.

Rules.Title: Do not combine fields
Rules.Description: Two or more fields were declared in the same field declaration syntax.

Rules.Title: Do not combine attributes
Rules.Description: Two or more attributes appeared within the same set of square brackets.

Rules.Title: Attributes must not share line
Rules.Description: An attribute is placed on the same line of code as another attribute or element.

Rules.Title: Using directives must be qualified
Rules.Description: A using directive is not qualified.

Rules.Title: Enum values should be on separate lines
Rules.Description: Multiple enum values are placed on the same line of code.

Rules.Title: Elements should have the same indentation
Rules.Description: Two sibling elements which each start on their own line have different levels of indentation.

Rules.Title: Use literals suffix notation instead of casting
Rules.Description: Use literal suffix notation instead of casting.

Rules.Title: Use tuple syntax
Rules.Description: Use tuple syntax instead of the underlying ValueTuple implementation type.

Rules.Title: Refer to tuple elements by name
Rules.Description: An element of a tuple was referenced by its metadata name when an element name is available.

Rules.Title: Using directives must be placed correctly
Rules.Description: A C# using directive is placed outside of a namespace element.

Rules.Title: Elements must appear in the correct order
Rules.Description: An element within a C# code file is out of order in relation to the other elements in the code.

Rules.Title: Elements must be ordered by access
Rules.Description: An element within a C# code file is out of order within regard to access level, in relation to other elements in the code.

Rules.Title: Constants must appear before fields
Rules.Description: A constant field is placed beneath a non-constant field.

Rules.Title: Static elements must appear before instance elements
Rules.Description: A static element is positioned beneath an instance element of the same type.

Rules.Title: Partial elements must declare access
Rules.Description: The partial element does not have an access modifier defined.

Rules.Title: Declaration keywords must follow order
Rules.Description: The keywords within the declaration of an element do not follow a standard ordering scheme.

Rules.Title: Protected must come before internal
Rules.Description: The keyword protected is positioned after the keyword internal within the declaration of a protected internal C# element.

Rules.Title: System using directives must be placed before other using directives
Rules.Description: A using directive which declares a member of the System namespace appears after a using directive which declares a member of a different namespace, within a C# code file.

Rules.Title: Using alias directives must be placed after other using directives
Rules.Description: A using-alias directive is positioned before a regular using directive.

Rules.Title: Using directives must be ordered alphabetically by namespace
Rules.Description: The using directives within a C# code file are not sorted alphabetically by namespace.

Rules.Title: Using alias directives must be ordered alphabetically by alias name
Rules.Description: The using-alias directives within a C# code file are not sorted alphabetically by alias name.

Rules.Title: Property accessors must follow order
Rules.Description: A get accessor appears after a set accessor within a property or indexer.

Rules.Title: Event accessors must follow order
Rules.Description: An add accessor appears after a remove accessor within an event.

Rules.Title: Readonly elements must appear before non readonly elements
Rules.Description: A readonly field is positioned beneath a non-readonly field.

Rules.Title: Instance readonly elements must appear before instance non readonly elements
Rules.Description: An instance readonly element is positioned beneath an instance non-readonly element of the same type.

Rules.Title: Using static directives must be placed at the correct location
Rules.Description: A using static directive is positioned at the wrong location (before a regular using directive or after an alias using directive).

Rules.Title: Using static directives must be ordered alphabetically
Rules.Description: The using static directives within a C# code file are not sorted alphabetically by full type name.

Rules.Title: Element must begin with upper case letter
Rules.Description: The name of a C# element does not begin with an upper-case letter.

Rules.Title: Element must begin with lower case letter
Rules.Description: There are currently no situations in which this rule will fire.

Rules.Title: Interface names must begin with I
Rules.Description: The name of a C# interface does not begin with the capital letter I.

Rules.Title: Const field names must begin with upper case letter
Rules.Description: The name of a constant C# field should begin with an upper-case letter.

Rules.Title: Non private readonly fields must begin with upper case letter
Rules.Description: The name of a non-private readonly C# field should being with an upper-case letter.

Rules.Title: Field names must not use hungarian notation
Rules.Description: The name of a field or variable in C# uses Hungarian notation.

Rules.Title: Field names must begin with lower case letter
Rules.Description: The name of a field in C# does not begin with a lower-case letter.

Rules.Title: Accessible fields must begin with upper case letter
Rules.Description: The name of a public or internal field in C# does not begin with an upper-case letter.

Rules.Title: Variable names must not be prefixed
Rules.Description: A field name in C# is prefixed with m_ or s_.

Rules.Title: Field names must not begin with underscore
Rules.Description: A field name in C# begins with an underscore.

Rules.Title: Field names must not contain underscore
Rules.Description: A field name in C# contains an underscore.

Rules.Title: Static readonly fields must begin with upper case letter
Rules.Description: The name of a static readonly field does not begin with an upper-case letter.

Rules.Title: Variable names must begin with lower case letter
Rules.Description: The name of a variable in C# does not begin with a lower-case letter.

Rules.Title: Parameter names must begin with lower case letter
Rules.Description: The name of a parameter in C# does not begin with a lower-case letter.

Rules.Title: Type parameter names must begin with T
Rules.Description: The name of a C# type parameter does not begin with the capital letter T.

Rules.Title: Tuple element names should use correct casing
Rules.Description: Element names within a tuple type should have the correct casing.

Rules.Title: Statement must not use unnecessary parenthesis
Rules.Description: A C# statement contains parenthesis which are unnecessary and should be removed.

Rules.Title: Access modifier must be declared
Rules.Description: The access modifier for a C# element has not been explicitly defined.

Rules.Title: Fields must be private
Rules.Description: A field within a C# class has an access modifier other than private.

Rules.Title: File may only contain ASingle type
Rules.Description: A C# code file contains more than one unique type.

Rules.Title: File may only contain ASingle namespace
Rules.Description: A C# code file contains more than one namespace.

Rules.Title: Code analysis suppression must have justification
Rules.Description: A Code Analysis SuppressMessage attribute does not include a justification.

Rules.Title: Debug assert must provide message text
Rules.Description: A call to Debug.Assert in C# code does not include a descriptive message.

Rules.Title: Debug fail must provide message text
Rules.Description: A call to Debug.Fail in C# code does not include a descriptive message.

Rules.Title: Arithmetic expressions must declare precedence
Rules.Description: A C# statement contains a complex arithmetic expression which omits parenthesis around operators.

Rules.Title: Conditional expressions must declare precedence
Rules.Description: A C# statement contains a complex conditional expression which omits parenthesis around operators.

Rules.Title: Remove unnecessary code
Rules.Description: A C# file contains code which is unnecessary and can be removed without changing the overall logic of the code.

Rules.Title: Remove delegate parenthesis when possible
Rules.Description: A call to a C# anonymous method does not contain any method parameters, yet the statement still includes parenthesis.

Rules.Title: Attribute constructor must not use unnecessary parenthesis
Rules.Description: An attribute declaration does not contain any parameters, yet it still includes parenthesis.

Rules.Title: Store files as utf8
Rules.Description: The encoding of the file is not UTF-8 with byte order mark.

Rules.Title: Use trailing commas in multi line initializers
Rules.Description: A multi-line initializer should use a comma on the last item.

Rules.Title: Tuple types in signatures should have element names
Rules.Description: Tuple types appearing in member declarations should have explicitly named tuple elements.

Rules.Title: Braces for multi line statements must not share line
Rules.Description: The opening or closing brace within a C# statement, element, or expression is not placed on its own line.

Rules.Title: Statement must not be on single line
Rules.Description: A C# statement containing opening and closing braces is written completely on a single line.

Rules.Title: Element must not be on single line
Rules.Description: A C# element containing opening and closing braces is written completely on a single line.

Rules.Title: Braces must not be omitted
Rules.Description: The opening and closing braces for a C# statement have been omitted.

Rules.Title: All accessors must be single line or multi line
Rules.Description: Within a C# property, indexer or event, at least one of the child accessors is written on a single line, and at least one of the child accessors is written across multiple lines.

Rules.Title: Opening braces must not be followed by blank line
Rules.Description: An opening brace within a C# element, statement, or expression is followed by a blank line.

Rules.Title: Element documentation headers must not be followed by blank line
Rules.Description: An element documentation header above a C# element is followed by a blank line.

Rules.Title: Code must not contain multiple blank lines in ARow
Rules.Description: The C# code contains multiple blank lines in a row.

Rules.Title: Closing braces must not be preceded by blank line
Rules.Description: A closing brace within a C# element, statement, or expression is preceded by a blank line.

Rules.Title: Opening braces must not be preceded by blank line
Rules.Description: An opening brace within a C# element, statement, or expression is preceded by a blank line.

Rules.Title: Chained statement blocks must not be preceded by blank line
Rules.Description: Chained C# statements are separated by a blank line.

Rules.Title: While do footer must not be preceded by blank line
Rules.Description: The while footer at the bottom of a do-while statement is separated from the statement by a blank line.

Rules.Title: Single line comments must not be followed by blank line
Rules.Description: A single-line comment within C# code is followed by a blank line.

Rules.Title: Closing brace must be followed by blank line
Rules.Description: A closing brace within a C# element, statement, or expression is not followed by a blank line.

Rules.Title: Element documentation header must be preceded by blank line
Rules.Description: An element documentation header above a C# element is not preceded by a blank line.

Rules.Title: Single line comment must be preceded by blank line
Rules.Description: A single-line comment within C# code is not preceded by a blank line.

Rules.Title: Elements must be separated by blank line
Rules.Description: Adjacent C# elements are not separated by a blank line.

Rules.Title: Code must not contain blank lines at start of file
Rules.Description: The code file has blank lines at the start.

Rules.Title: Use line endings correctly at end of file
Rules.Description: The line endings at the end of a file do not match the settings for the project.

Rules.Title: Braces must not be omitted from multi line child statement
Rules.Description: The opening and closing braces for a multi-line C# statement have been omitted.

Rules.Title: Use braces consistently
Rules.Description: The opening and closing braces of a chained if/else if/else construct were included for some clauses, but omitted for others.

Rules.Title: Elements must be documented
Rules.Description: A C# code element is missing a documentation header.

Rules.Title: Partial elements must be documented
Rules.Description: A C# partial element is missing a documentation header.

Rules.Title: Enumeration items must be documented
Rules.Description: An item within a C# enumeration is missing an Xml documentation header.

Rules.Title: Documentation must contain valid xml
Rules.Description: The Xml within a C# element's document header is badly formed.

Rules.Title: Element documentation must have summary
Rules.Description: The Xml header documentation for a C# element is missing a <summary> tag.

Rules.Title: Partial element documentation must have summary
Rules.Description: The <summary> or <content> tag within the documentation header for a C# code element is missing or empty.

Rules.Title: Element documentation must have summary text
Rules.Description: The <summary> tag within the documentation header for a C# code element is empty.

Rules.Title: Partial element documentation must have summary text
Rules.Description: The <summary> or <content> tag within the documentation header for a C# code element is empty.

Rules.Title: Element documentation must not have default summary
Rules.Description: The <summary> tag within an element's Xml header documentation contains the default text generated by Visual Studio during the creation of the element.

Rules.Title: Property documentation must have value
Rules.Description: The Xml header documentation for a C# property does not contain a <value> tag.

Rules.Title: Property documentation must have value text
Rules.Description: The Xml header documentation for a C# property contains an empty <value> tag.

Rules.Title: Element parameters must be documented
Rules.Description: A C# method, constructor, delegate or indexer element is missing documentation for one or more of its parameters.

Rules.Title: Element parameter documentation must match element parameters
Rules.Description: The documentation describing the parameters to a C# method, constructor, delegate or indexer element does not match the actual parameters on the element.

Rules.Title: Element parameter documentation must declare parameter name
Rules.Description: A <param> tag within a C# element's documentation header is missing a name attribute containing the name of the parameter.

Rules.Title: Element parameter documentation must have text
Rules.Description: A <param> tag within a C# element's documentation header is empty.

Rules.Title: Element return value must be documented
Rules.Description: A C# element is missing documentation for its return value.

Rules.Title: Element return value documentation must have text
Rules.Description: The <returns> tag within a C# element's documentation header is empty.

Rules.Title: Void return value must not be documented
Rules.Description: A C# code element does not contain a return value, or returns void, but the documentation header for the element contains a <returns> tag.

Rules.Title: Generic type parameters must be documented
Rules.Description: A generic C# element is missing documentation for one or more of its generic type parameters.

Rules.Title: Generic type parameters must be documented partial class
Rules.Description: A generic, partial C# element is missing documentation for one or more of its generic type parameters, and the documentation for the element contains a <summary> tag.

Rules.Title: Generic type parameter documentation must match type parameters
Rules.Description: The <typeparam> tags within the Xml header documentation for a generic C# element do not match the generic type parameters on the element.

Rules.Title: Generic type parameter documentation must declare parameter name
Rules.Description: A <typeparam> tag within the Xml header documentation for a generic C# element is missing a name attribute, or contains an empty name attribute.

Rules.Title: Generic type parameter documentation must have text
Rules.Description: A <typeparam> tag within the Xml header documentation for a generic C# element is empty.

Rules.Title: Property summary documentation must match accessors
Rules.Description: The documentation text within a C# property's <summary> tag does not match the accessors within the property.

Rules.Title: Property summary documentation must omit set accessor with restricted access
Rules.Description: The documentation text within a C# property's <summary> tag takes into account all of the accessors within the property, but one of the accessors has limited access.

Rules.Title: Element documentation must not be copied and pasted
Rules.Description: The Xml documentation for a C# element contains two or more identical entries, indicating that the documentation has been copied and pasted.

Rules.Title: Single line comments must not use documentation style slashes
Rules.Description: The C# code contains a single-line comment which begins with three forward slashes in a row.

Rules.Title: Documentation text must not be empty
Rules.Description: The Xml header documentation for a C# code element contains an empty tag.

Rules.Title: Documentation text must begin with ACapital letter
Rules.Description: A section of the Xml header documentation for a C# element does not begin with a capital letter.

Rules.Title: Documentation text must end with APeriod
Rules.Description: A section of the Xml header documentation for a C# element does not end with a period (also known as a full stop).

Rules.Title: Documentation text must contain whitespace
Rules.Description: A section of the Xml header documentation for a C# element does not contain any whitespace between words.

Rules.Title: Documentation must meet character percentage
Rules.Description: A section of the Xml header documentation for a C# element does not contain enough alphabetic characters.

Rules.Title: Documentation text must meet minimum character length
Rules.Description: From StyleCop 4.5 this rule is disabled by default.

Rules.Title: File must have header
Rules.Description: A C# code file is missing a standard file header.

Rules.Title: File header must show copyright
Rules.Description: The file header at the top of a C# code file is missing a copyright tag.

Rules.Title: File header must have copyright text
Rules.Description: The file header at the top of a C# code file is missing copyright text.

Rules.Title: File header copyright text must match
Rules.Description: The file header at the top of a C# code file does not contain the appropriate copyright text.

Rules.Title: File header must contain file name
Rules.Description: The file header at the top of a C# code file is missing the file name.

Rules.Title: File header file name documentation must match file name
Rules.Description: The file tag within the file header at the top of a C# code file does not contain the name of the file.

Rules.Title: File header must have summary
Rules.Description: The file header at the top of a C# code file does not contain a filled-in summary tag.

Rules.Title: File header must have valid company text
Rules.Description: The file header at the top of a C# code file does not contain company name text.

Rules.Title: File header company name text must match
Rules.Description: The file header at the top of a C# code file does not contain the appropriate company name text.

Rules.Title: Constructor summary documentation must begin with standard text
Rules.Description: The XML documentation header for a C# constructor does not contain the appropriate summary text.

Rules.Title: Destructor summary documentation must begin with standard text
Rules.Description: The Xml documentation header for a C# finalizer does not contain the appropriate summary text.

Rules.Title: Documentation headers must not contain blank lines
Rules.Description: A section within the Xml documentation header for a C# element contains blank lines.

Rules.Title: Included documentation file does not exist
Rules.Description: An included Xml documentation file does not exist.

Rules.Title: Included documentation XPath does not exist
Rules.Description: An included Xml documentation link contains an invalid path.

Rules.Title: Include node does not contain valid file and path
Rules.Description: An include tag within an Xml documentation header does not contain valid file and path attribute.

Rules.Title: Inherit doc must be used with inheriting class
Rules.Description: <inheritdoc> has been used on an element that doesn't inherit from a base class or implement an interface.

Rules.Title: File name must match type name
Rules.Description: The file name of a C# code file does not match the first type declared in the file.

Rules.Title: Element documentation must be spelled correctly
Rules.Description: The element documentation for the element contains one or more spelling mistakes or unrecognized words.

Rules.Title: Do not use placeholder elements
Rules.Description: The documentation for the element contains one or more <placeholder> elements.

Rules.Title: Enable xml documentation output
Rules.Description: This rule was moved to SA0001

Rules.Title: Do not prefix local members with this
Rules.Description: A call to an instance member of the local class or a base class is prefixed with 'this.', within a C# code file.

Rules.Title: Field names must begin with underscore
Rules.Description: A field name does not begin with an underscore.

Rules.Title: Static field names must begin with underscore
Rules.Description: A static field name does not begin with an underscore.
